[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/metrics.rs] [Function: handle_forge_metrics()] [Error message leak] On serialization failure, the error is returned in the response body - does the error message leak internal implementation details? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/metrics.rs] [Function: handle_json_metrics_request()] [Encoder bypass] The function uses JsonEncoder to format metrics - can an attacker craft metric names or labels that break the JSON encoding and cause injection attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/metrics.rs] [Function: handle_metrics_request()] [Text encoding] Using TextEncoder for Prometheus format - can metric labels with special characters cause parsing errors in downstream monitoring systems? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/identity_information.rs] [Function: handle_identity_information_request()] [Peer ID exposure] The endpoint exposes peer IDs for validator and fullnode networks - can an attacker use these IDs to target specific validators in eclipse or Sybil attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/identity_information.rs] [Function: handle_identity_information_request()] [Network enumeration] The function reveals all configured networks and their IDs - can an attacker map the validator's network topology and identify all network connections? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/identity_information.rs] [Function: get_identity_information()] [Iterator safety] The function iterates over full_node_networks without bounds checking - can malformed or malicious network configurations cause panics? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/identity_information.rs] [Function: get_identity_information()] [Format string injection] The output uses format! macros - if peer IDs or network IDs contain special characters, can they break the output format? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/identity_information.rs] [Function: get_identity_information()] [Validator identification] Can an attacker use the validator_network presence check to definitively identify which nodes are validators for targeted attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: handle_peer_information_request()] [Massive data exposure] This endpoint exposes connection metadata, monitoring metadata, trusted peers, state sync data, and internal client state - can attackers use this comprehensive information to launch sophisticated network attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Performance DoS] The function sorts all peers multiple times and performs numerous iterations - can an attacker with many peer connections cause this function to consume excessive CPU time? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Memory exhaustion] The function builds a large Vec<String> with detailed information for each peer - with thousands of peers, can this cause excessive memory allocation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_peer_connection_metadata()] [Connection state leak] The function reveals connection states and metadata including IP addresses and ports - can attackers use this to map validator network topology for eclipse attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_peer_connection_metadata()] [JSON serialization vulnerability] Connection metadata is serialized using serde_json::to_string with unwrap_or_default - what happens if serialization fails due to malicious data in connection metadata? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_trusted_peers()] [Validator set exposure] The function exposes the complete validator set and seed peers - can attackers use this to identify all validators for coordinated attacks or to plan Sybil attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_trusted_peers()] [BTreeMap sorting overhead] Trusted peers are copied into a BTreeMap for sorting - with large validator sets, can this cause performance degradation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_peer_monitoring_metadata()] [Debug format leak] Detailed metadata uses Debug formatting {:?} - can this leak sensitive internal state that should not be exposed? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_state_sync_metadata()] [State sync intelligence] The function exposes priority peers, regular peers, global data summary, peer scores, bucket IDs, and request/response counts - can attackers use this to identify weak peers to exploit or to understand state sync behavior for attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_state_sync_metadata()] [Data client exposure] The function calls aptos_data_client methods that may perform expensive operations - can repeated requests cause performance degradation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_internal_client_state()] [Internal state leak] This exposes internal_client_state which may contain sensitive operational data - what attack vectors does this enable? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/system_information.rs] [Function: handle_system_information_request()] [Version fingerprinting] The endpoint exposes build information including version, commit hash, and build timestamp - can attackers use this to identify vulnerable software versions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/system_information.rs] [Function: get_system_information_json()] [System enumeration] The function calls aptos_telemetry::system_information which may expose OS details, CPU info, memory - can attackers use this for targeted exploits? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/system_information.rs] [Function: get_system_information_json()] [JSON error handling] On serialization failure, the error message is returned - does the error leak file paths or internal state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/system_information.rs] [Function: get_system_information_json()] [Build info extension] The function extends system_information with build_information!() macro - can this macro include sensitive build-time data? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/inspection_client.rs] [Function: new()] [URL validation] The client is created with a Url without validation - can an attacker provide a malicious URL that causes SSRF when requests are made? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/inspection_client.rs] [Function: get_node_metric_i64()] [Type confusion] The function converts string values to i64 - can malicious metric values cause parsing errors or integer overflow? (Low)
